diagrams.description: Landscape ecology emerged in 1930s Europe with geographer Carl Troll coining the term landscape ecology (1939) and emphasizing spatial patterns. The 1940s-50s saw early European development focusing on landscape classification and cultural landscapes. The 1960s brought island biogeography theory (MacArthur and Wilson, 1967) providing theoretical foundations for understanding species-area relationships. The 1970s witnessed landscape ecology spreading to North America with Richard Forman and Michel Godron's pioneering work on landscape structure and patch dynamics. The 1980s marked formalization as a discipline with establishment of the International Association for Landscape Ecology (IALE, 1982), publication of foundational textbooks, and development of landscape metrics. The 1990s brought GIS and remote sensing integration, FRAGSTATS software development (McGarigal, 1995), metapopulation theory application to landscapes, and conservation biology integration. The 2000s advanced with ecosystem services framework incorporation, climate change considerations, urban landscape ecology emergence, and landscape genetics development. The 2010s-2020s continue with big data and machine learning applications, landscape connectivity modeling, telecoupling (distant interactions), sustainable landscape design, nature-based solutions, and landscape-scale climate adaptation strategies becoming central to conservation and land management practices.
